fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Let C and D be categories, let L : C \to D and R : D \to C be functors, then this is called a pair of adjoint functors with L left adjoint and R right adjoint, denoted L \dashv R, if there exists a natural isomorphism between the hom-functors of the following form: \hom _D(L(-), -) \cong \hom _C(-, R(-)) which means \forall c\in C, d\in D there is a bijection of hom-sets: \begin {align*} \hom _D(L(c), d) &\xrightarrow {\cong } \hom _C(c, R(d)) \\ \{ L(c) \xrightarrow {f} d \} &\mapsto \{ c \xrightarrow {\hat {f}} R(d) \} \end {align*} which is natural in both c and d. This isomorphism is the adjunction isomorphism and the image \bar {f} of a morphism f under this isomorphism is called the adjunct of f, and vice versa.
This note is about the category theory and its applications. Instead of reading a well-organized book, I prefer to write down the things I learned from ncatlab and papers.

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
Intuitively, a category is a collection of objects and arrows between them, such arrows can be composed and there is an identity arrow for each object.
There are commonly two ways to define a category, which are equivalent in usual foundations of mathematics. One of them generalizes the notion of internal category nicely while the other one is more convenient for enriched category.
The major difference is whether they use a single collection of all morphisms or several collections of morphisms (family of collections indexed by pairs of objects)

A category C consists
A collection of objects C_0 (\text {Ob}(C)).
A collection C_1 (\text {Mor}(C)) of morphisms (arrows).
For every morphism f there are an object s(f) (source, domain) and an object t(f) (target, codomain).
For every pair of morphisms f, g such that t(f) = s(g), there is a morphism g \circ f (composition) (Also written gf or f;g).
For every object x, there is a morphism \text {id}_x (or 1_x) called identity.
The following properties hold:
s(g \circ f) = s(f) and t(g \circ f) = t(g).
s(1_x) = x and t(1_x) = x.
Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f when t(f) = s(g), and t(g) = s(h).
Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id}_x = f and \text {id}_y \circ f = f If the identity map and its axioms are omitted then one speaks of a semicategory.

fr:title.text: With a family of collections of morphisms
fr:title.fr:strong: With a family of collections of morphisms

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter:
A category C consists
A collection of objects C_0 (\text {Ob}(C)).
For every pair of objects x, y, a collection C_1(x, y) (\hom _C(x,y)) of morphisms from x to y.
For each pair of morphisms f in C_1(x,y) and g in C_1(y,z), a morphism g \circ f in C_1(x,z). called their composition.
For each object x, a morphism \text {id}_x in C_1(x,x) called the identity on x.
The following properties hold:
Composition is associative: h \circ (g \circ f) = (h \circ g) \circ f for all f in C_1(x,y), g in C_1(y,z), and h in C_1(z,w).
Composition satifies the identity laws: f \circ \text {id}_x = f and \text {id}_y \circ f = f for all f in C_1(x,y). Usually we write \text {Mor}(C) for the disjoint union \bigsqcup _{x,y \in C_0} C_1(x,y).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Its common to talk about some objects and their morphisms. Informally, a diagram in a category C consists of some objects of C connected by some morphisms of C.
This terminology is often used when speaking about limits or colimits of a diagram.
One formal way to define a diagram is to use a functor from a (very) small category to C. That is, a functor whose domain is a small category.
A category is said to be small if it has a samll set (i.e. a set but not a proper class) of objects and morphisms. In other words a small category is an internal category in category of sets.

We did not explain what a functor is, but it is very natural thought. Briefly, a functor is a homomorphism between two categories. It maps objects to objects and morphisms to morphisms, preserving the structure of the categories.

A functor F from a category C to a category D is a map sending each x\in C to an object F(x)\in D and each morphism f:x\to y in C to morphism F(f):F(x)\to F(y) in D, such that
Composition is preserved: F(g\circ f) = F(g)\circ F(f).
Identity is preserved: F(\text {id}_x) = \text {id}_{F(x)}.
For the sake of completeness, we state the definition of the functor category and the natural transformations between functors.

Let C and D be categories, the functor category D^C (or [C,D]) is the category whose
objects are functors from C to D.
morphisms are natural transformations between functors.
We state the concise functorial definition of diagrams of the shape of categories.
Let C be a category and J be a small category. A diagram of shape J in C is a functor X:J\to C. The category of J-shaped diagrams in C is the functor category C^J.
A limit of a diagram F:D\to C is an object \lim F of C equipped with morphisms to the objects F(d) for all d\in D, such that everything in sight commutes.

For a locally small category C, the hom functor is the functor \hom _C : C^{\text {op}} \times C \to \text {Set} from the product category of the opposite category of C and C into the category of sets \text {Set}.

fr:ul.fr:li: An object (c,c') \in C^{\text {op}} \times C is mapped to the set \hom _C(c, c') in \text {Set}, the set of morphisms c \to c' in C.
A morphism (f,g) : (c, c') \to (d, d') in the product category will be sent to the function \hom _C((f,g)) : \hom _C(c, c') \to \hom _C(d, d') which maps h \mapsto g \circ h \circ f

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A presheaf on a small category C is a functor F : C^{\text {op}} \to \text {Set} from the opposite category of C to the category of sets. Similar to category of functors, we can define the category of presheaves on C, denoted \text {Set}^{C^{\text {op}}}.

Representability is one of the most fundamental concepts of category theory, with close ties to the notion of adjoint functor and the Yoneda lemma. It is the crucial concept underlying the idea of universal property.

For a locally small category C, a presheaf on C, which is of the form F : C^{\text {op}} \to \text {Set}, is representable if it is natural isomorphic to a hom-functor h_X: \hom _C(-, X) for some object X in C, which sends an object U\in C to the hom-set \hom _C(U,X). The object is determined uniquely up to isomorphism in C, and is called a representing object of the presheaf F.

Let C and D be categories, let L : C \to D and R : D \to C be functors, then this is called a pair of adjoint functors with L left adjoint and R right adjoint, denoted L \dashv R, if there exists a natural isomorphism between the hom-functors of the following form: \hom _D(L(-), -) \cong \hom _C(-, R(-)) which means \forall c\in C, d\in D there is a bijection of hom-sets: \begin {align*} \hom _D(L(c), d) &\xrightarrow {\cong } \hom _C(c, R(d)) \\ \{ L(c) \xrightarrow {f} d \} &\mapsto \{ c \xrightarrow {\hat {f}} R(d) \} \end {align*} which is natural in both c and d. This isomorphism is the adjunction isomorphism and the image \bar {f} of a morphism f under this isomorphism is called the adjunct of f, and vice versa.

Consider a pair of adjoint functors L \dashv R, \forall c\in C the adjunct of the identity morphism \text {id}_{L(c)} is the unit morphism of the adjunction at that object, denoted by \eta _c = \hat {\text {id}_{L(c)}} : c \to R(L(c)) and the adjunct of the identity morphism \text {id}_{R(d)} is the counit morphism of the adjunction at that object, denoted by \varepsilon _d = \text {id}_{R(d)} : L(R(d)) \to d

Now we reach an important theorem in category theory, the Yoneda lemma, an elementary but central result in category theory, sheaf and topos theory. It says that the set of morphism from a representable presheaf into an arbitrary presheaf X is in natural bijection with set X(c) assigned by X to the representing object c.

For a locally small category C, we denote [C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}] := \text {Func}(C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}) for the functor category out of the opposite category of C into \text {Set}, the category of sets. This is also called the presheaf category of C. The functor Y : C \to [C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}] defined by c \mapsto \hom _C(-, c) from C to its presheaf category is called the Yoneda embedding, which sends each object of c into the hom-functor into that object, also called the presheaf represented by c.

From the exponential we know that the Yoneda embedding is just the adjunct of the hom-functor \hom _C(-, -) under the functor category adjunction: \hom (C ^{\text {op}} \times C, \text {Set}) \cong \hom (C, [C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}]) in the closed symmetric monoidal category

Let C be a locally small category, with the presheaf category [C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}]. For any presheaf X \in [C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}], there is a canonical isomorphism \hom _{[C^{\text {op}}, \text {Set}]}(\hom _C(-, c), X) \cong X(c) between the hom-set of presheaf morphism from the representable presheaf h_c = \hom _C(-,c) to X, and the value of X at c.
